name: Citrus Canker
description: A contagious bacterial infection affecting citrus trees, caused by Xanthomonas citri. It produces characteristic raised, corky lesions on fruit, leaves, and stems, severely impacting fruit quality and marketability.

stages.initial_infection: Appears as small, slightly raised, blister-like spots on leaves and fruit. On leaves, these spots are often surrounded by a distinct, oily-looking yellow halo.
stages.advanced_infection: The lesions grow larger, becoming brown, raised, and corky with a rough, crater-like texture, as seen in the image. The yellow halo may disappear. The infection can lead to premature leaf and fruit drop and dieback of twigs.

causes: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas citri. It spreads through wind-driven rain, overhead irrigation, and contaminated gardening tools, clothing, or equipment. The bacteria enter the plant through natural pores (stomata) or wounds, especially those created by the citrus leafminer insect.
risk_factors: Warm, wet, and windy weather conditions create the perfect storm for infection and spread. High humidity and rainfall are major contributors. Young, new growth is the most susceptible to infection.
preventive_measures: Plant certified disease-free trees. Use windbreaks to protect groves from wind-driven rain. Control citrus leafminer populations to reduce wounds. Sanitize all pruning tools between trees. Applying protective copper-based bactericide sprays before the rainy season can help protect new growth.
solution: There is no cure for Citrus Canker once a tree is infected; management focuses on preventing its spread. Prune and destroy infected branches during dry weather to reduce bacterial load. Regularly apply copper-based sprays to protect healthy tissue. In many commercial growing regions, infected trees are legally required to be removed and destroyed to protect nearby groves.
